SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was interrupted at about midnight on Tuesday night, I had just made the point that, despite this legislation faithfully implementing the four key principles and the policy detail of our election commitment, Labor persists in misrepresenting it. Rather than an end to a cooperative era, as Mr McMullan had claimed, in contrast to that false claim this legislation represents the very beginning of the cooperative era. It is an end to the standover tactics employed by a diminishing union movement desperate to cling to the relics of the past.

PARA.BREAK: There is clear community support for the bill, despite claims to the contrary by unions. It is in the interests of employees and employers, of the Australian economy overall and, most importantly, in the interests of the unemployed for the Senate to pass the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amend ment Bill as presented. We should not bow to the trade unions and their minions sitting on the opposition benches of this chamber and in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that more than half of senators opposite retain membership of trade unions. One can question whether there is a conflict of interest on the part of those senators in seeking to oppose and change this legislation. They have a direct conflict of interest as members of unions seeking to change this legislation, simply because the trade union movement is opposed to any reduction in power that will result from this legislation. That is a question that ought to be asked in the light of their performance in the last 24 hours or so.

Too many senators opposite have links with the trade union movement and have used that movement as a stepping stone into this place. In contrast, too few of them have direct practical experience of private business as employers. They have approached the government's industrial relations reforms from a biased position protective of trade unions. It is the unions and in particular the ACTU's continued campaign of fear and loathing promised during the election campaign which has caused some unnecessary anxiety in the community about this legislation.

I understand that some 80 community groups have appealed to the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens and the Independents to keep the government to its election commitment that no Australian worker will be worse off under our new industrial relations laws. We will honour that commitment. It is a fundamental part of the government's policy to release Australian workers and their families from the Labor imposed industrial relations yoke and to achieve a better quality of life as a result.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised that, for the first time in Australia, people will be permitted to reach agreement at the workplace level without unwanted, undesired and unnecessary third‐party intrusion. It is worth noting in that context that a recent research study published in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser shows that in South Australia union membership has fallen to 15.5 per cent of the work force—a fall of more than 40 per cent over the last 15 years. That is how representative this mob opposite are—15 per cent of the work force. In relation to comments I have made about undesired third‐party intrusion, that study also showed that employers were unhappy with unions brokering agreements in which they `simply walk in with a template plan asking for a 20 per cent increase over two years and demand the employer sign the agreement'.

That is what has been happening. We have not had any genuine enterprise negotiations relevant to local employment conditions and to the needs of local firms under Labor's legislation. We have had these enforced template agreements. We need to remember that when we hear this nonsense opposite about workers being forced to sign agreements under this legislation, because it is the unions that have forced employers to sign agreements under the existing legislation.

Passage of this bill will mean that Australian workers will be released from this union stranglehold which has decreed when, where and how people may perform their jobs. There will be freedom to negotiate. Although unions will still have their place, that place will only be relevant if members want them involved. So this government retains its commitment that no Australian worker will be worse off under this legislation.

Labor's scaremongering about the working poor is a blatant misrepresentation of the government's industrial relations reform. Quite specifically, under this legislation, the safety nets are in place, no worker will be subjected to duress in the process of formulating a workplace agreement and workers will be freed of unwanted union interference. A major shortcoming of Labor's existing laws is that a union without any members in a workplace is nevertheless able to argue against various working conditions agreed in that non-union workplace and they could actually contest that agreement in the Industrial Relations Commission.

The previous Labor government's enterprise flexibility agreements, supposedly designed for the non-union sector, could not be established without union involvement or approval by the Industrial Relations Commission. A union with no connections to a particular work force could argue against conditions in that workplace. Under our bill, union members can choose to remain with their respective unions. Unions will still have a role to play in Australia's industrial relations, as I said earlier, if the worker wants that involvement.

There are many safeguards for employees built into the legislation, including the role of the Employment Advocate to investigate alleged breaches of Australian workplace agreements. It is to the Labor Party's and the trade union's everlasting detriment that they have stirred up unwarranted anxiety in the community about the changes proposed in this bill simply by misrepresenting the facts of the legislation. The community's anxieties are fictional, not factual. Employees will not be worse off. The legislation will give hope to the unemployed, encourage the private sector to employ and improve our international competitiveness, which will in turn reduce our national debt.

Under Labor, the employment sector, small business in particular, was too scared to employ because of the draconian restrictions placed on employers by Labor's legislation. By contrast, this government's new legislation has a central theme of cooperation with two parties agreeing to a contract of mutual benefit, taking us away from the dispute and fear regime of the past decade. Individual skills will be recognised under the new legislation. Those who show talent in the workplace will be rewarded. Productivity will be encouraged. The rigid award system favoured by Labor will be freed up and employers will have the right to reward employees whom they value.

PARA.BREAK: The federal government's industrial relations legislation will remove restrictions on employers hiring permanent part-time employees, representing a significant benefit to many working women currently juggling work and family responsibilities. Our bill will return respectability to permanent part-time work. The Labor Party has, for years, paid lip‐service to the plight of women in the workplace and those with family responsibili ties returning to the workplace. Yet current restrictions on permanent part-time employees have caused a vast increase in the numbers of casual workers who do not have the security of set hours with predictable pay levels, do not have the security of sick and recreational leave and do not have access to the myriad of other securities available to full-time workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Employees with family responsibilities need to know when they will be at work and how much income they will get. They also need to know that their job is safe and that they are secure. Yet current restrictions in place under some awards restrict permanent part-time work to at least 16 hours a week. If you are not going to work that minimum or more, you cannot be employed on a permanent part-time basis and have those benefits.

I return to some of the other benefits of this legislation, in particular for employers. In the past, employers have found themselves victims of boycotts and industrial disputes which have nothing to do with them. This legislation will return secondary boycott provisions. Employers will be able, under the Trade Practices Act, sections 45D and 45E, to turn to injunctive relief against unions which engage in secondary boycotts. Critically important to employers is the scrapping of the unworkable unfair dismissal laws. Once this bill is passed, both employers and employees will be able to get a fair go in this regard and this important facet of workplace activity will no longer be so badly out of kilter.

It is worth remembering that, of the 23,000 applications for unfair dismissal which have been filed, only 3,500 have been before the Industrial Relations Commission. Employers have been faced with the unhappy choice of either defending at great cost their reasons for sacking a person or agreeing to out of court settlements, even if that person had been caught stealing, had not fulfilled work obligations or had provided numerous other reasons for the termination of their employment.

Apart from the ridiculous havoc that failure to precisely adhere to procedural requirements wrought on employers, the sheer cost of Labor's unfair dismissal provisions rendered them unworkable. Under this legislation, they will no longer exist. The appeals of small business across the country will have been heard and acted upon.

In contrast to the positive legislation proposed by the government, the ACTU's living wage proposal to raise minimum wages by 30 per cent over the next three years is fraught with economic disaster. The imposition of this living wage would not lift Australian families out of poverty. Most poor households do not have a full-time employed member but are either predominantly in casual or part-time employment or, as a result of the previous Labor government's mismanagement, unemployed. So they are not going to benefit from this proposal. More than two million Australians, one‐quarter of the work force, are part-time employees.

Higher minimum wages would increase income levels of very few part-time workers and would be more likely to result in a reduction in the number of hours of work offered to them. Employment opportunities for Australian workers with low skill levels will also be adversely affected by such a sharp increase in minimum wages unless there is a uniform 30 per cent pay increase across the entire work force. That would neutralise the whole purpose of this living wage proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —But John Howard says you are going to increase wages.

—Senator Forshaw says that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, says we are going to increase wages. And we are, based on productivity improvement—not an across-the-board 30 per cent increase. It does not have any relationship to employment. That solid commitment is made, and that solid commitment to productivity based wage increases is a significant part of our policy. Current unemployment levels, again as a direct consequence of the policies of the previous government, are a disgrace, particularly with regard to young people. We have some 27.8 per cent unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these issues are of critical importance to the future of this country. This legislation is of critical importance. As I said at the outset, the complete failure of the previous Labor government to take any steps to reform the labour market, as distinct from their changes to other sectors of the economy—the financial markets, trade markets, industry protection and so on—is the remaining devastating legacy of this Labor government. That is why this particular piece of legislation is the most urgent reform required in this country. It should pass through the Senate without delay and without change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chapman has made something of conflict of interest. He probably knows, so I should declare proudly, up front, that I am a former Transport Workers Union official. I rise to speak in this debate on a number of issues which adversely impact on workers in the transport industry.
—How could the government raise conflict of interest today?

—Thank you, Senator Faulkner. I would have to agree with you. I would, however, like to record in Hansard John Howard's core promises to the Australian people about the coalition's IR policies, promises that he made prior to the last election. I am sure that this will not be the first or the last time this happens during this debate. In his address given in Canberra on 8 January 1996 to the 28th annual convention of the Young Liberals movement, Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under our policy, which I announce today, these arrangements will be concluded within a no disadvantage framework, whereby employees cannot be worse off. That is why our policy for the coming election contains an explicit guarantee. Under no circumstances will a Howard Government create a wages system which causes the wages of Australian workers to be cut. Under a Howard Government you cannot be worse off but you can be better off. I give you this rock solid guarantee.

As a Victorian senator, it was no great surprise to discover that after the election the coalition quickly discarded their moderate language. Victorian workers were lied to by Jeff Kennett and now Australian workers have been deceived by the federal coalition, led by John Howard. The three areas I wish to focus on are: the impact on independent contractors, known as owner‐drivers in the transport industry; the impact on superannuation award payments; and the impact of section 152 of the bill.

BREAK.PARA: On 23 July 1992, the Industrial Relations Commission was given power to review unfair contracts. On 30 March 1994, these powers transferred to the Industrial Relations Court. These powers allowed the court to vary a contract and set aside the whole or part of the contract. The court can intervene if it finds a contract for services is either unfair or harsh.

Section 127A(4) lists the following factors for the court to consider in deciding if a contract is unfair or harsh: the relative bargaining strength of the parties to the contract; whether there was any undue influence or pressure exerted on the party; and whether the contract provides for total remuneration which is less than that of an employee performing similar work. These provisions were introduced both to deal with the shams created by some employers to avoid award requirements and in recognition of the changing nature of the work force.

Some senators may believe that an owner-driver contractor should not be considered an industrial relationship. Let me deal with this immediately. An owner-driver contract is an industrial relationship. This is indicated by the following common practices in the industry. Owner-drivers perform work at the direction and control of their prime contractor. Many receive annual leave, sick leave and RDO entitlements and are paid without invoicing. Many operate equipment which is owned and installed by the prime contractor. Many are captive and prohibited from working for other parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are called dedicated contractors, actually.

—We call them owner-drivers, Senator. Their vehicles are coated with the prime contractor's colours and the driver wears company uniform and insignia. Allow me to give you a real life example. Mick Nealor is an owner-driver for Comet of Footscray Road in Melbourne. Mick works alongside 40 employee drivers in his yard. Mick drives a truck which is painted in the same Comet colours as the employee truck drivers. Mick wears the same uniform as the employee driver. Mick will be directed in his work by the same Comet supervisor. Mick's hours of work will be governed by the same processes as the employee driver. The major industrial relations issues at Comet in respect of Mick will be determined by the same industrial relations managers who determine the same issues for their employee drivers at Comet. The fundamental point is that Mick's bargaining position is very similar to the bargaining position of the employees at Comet.

BREAK.PARA: Mick differs from an employee driver in the following critical respect. Mick is required to invest his own capital in the tools of the trade; namely, the truck. The tools of the trade in the transport industry, trucks, are expensive. Comet are required to invest millions of dollars in a very expensive transport fleet if they engage employees to work for them. The reason owner-drivers like Mick are an attractive work force for Comet is that it allows Comet to avoid this capital investment. Using Mick is a way for Comet to use their work force's private capital to purchase a transport fleet which they use. The result is that the employer does not risk the investment in the capital but rather the risk is transferred to Comet's labour force. In the light of these risks it could easily be argued that the owner-driver should be afforded greater protection, not less.

Section 127A is the only provision in the act that recognises that owner-drivers have any rights. There is no minimum pay or conditions set out anywhere in the rest of the act. The coalition's bill leaves owner-drivers without any protective framework of rights and with no scope to ensure fair minimum conditions and rates of pay. Owner-drivers will be forced into the common law system. This system treats owner-drivers as business people with commercial interests rather than workers.

Section 127A provided unlimited means of addressing examples of unfairness encountered by owner-drivers. This section does not set minimum wages or conditions. Instead, it has been used as a means of addressing specific instances of unfairness, including: contracts entered into as a result of misleading and deceptive conduct—you simply have to pick up the Herald‐Sun and look in the courier section every day in the jobs column to see the riches promised; unfair contracts characterised by a clear inequality of bargaining power between the parties; contracts entered into by illiterate and uninformed workers; the termination of contracts of 10 to 20 years standing without notice; and the failure to pay owner-drivers an amount which corresponds with an award rate for the labour component of their work.

In Victoria there has been an explosion of owner-drivers. Many employers have sought to exploit this situation by forcing the employees—no choice involved—to become owner-drivers so that an employer can transfer liabilities to the new owner-driver. The courier industry is a depressing example of this phenomenon. In 1988 there were 18 courier companies in Victoria. In 1996 there are 275. This explosion in the number of owner‐drivers means that there is an absolute inequality in bargaining power when seeking work. This means that companies can unilaterally set conditions. Negotiations over terms of employment are non-existent. Many drivers are shown a contract, asked to sign and not even given a copy of the contract they have signed.

The unfairness and exploitation encountered by courier drivers across the industry is reflected in the following examples of contracts in Victoria. Common contracts include: workcover, superannuation and insurance obligations on the driver rather than on the company; radio fees; administration fees; aerial fees; uniform fees; delays between four and six weeks in being paid; and the company has the right to unilaterally alter rates and conditions. These fees that I have listed are simply deducted from the driver's pay.

If a driver were to terminate his contract he would discover many of the following: up to 10 weeks delay in being paid outstanding entitlements; a range of hidden extras which are deducted from the driver's last pay, including radio removal fees, uniform fees again and fees for replacing signage; and being prevented from working for a customer after termination. The individual courier owner‐driver is not offered any choice but to accept these terms or look for work somewhere else.

The other significant area of the transport industry that has many owner‐drivers is the long‐distance interstate sector. Figures collated from employer organisations illustrate how harshly these drivers have fared in the last four years. On average in this sector, rates paid to drivers have increased by only 3.27 per cent. Over the same period the CPI transport index increased by 12.45 per cent. These increased costs have swamped the rate increase. The squeeze has meant a significant reduction for the driver's labour.

The consequences of these falling rates and a completely unregulated market include: as rates cannot keep up with the increasing costs of fuel, tyres and other costs, maintenance becomes ad hoc and less frequent, corners are cut and trade-offs are made, posing obvious threats to safety on our roads; and in order for drivers to make a living, they are forced to drive increased hours. This leads to breaches of driving hours regulations and also the increased use of medical stimulants and drugs in order to perform excessive hours of driving.

Section 127A of the act does not regulate minimum rates paid to owner‐drivers but at least accepts that there should be some parity between owner‐drivers and employees. If the Senate repeals section 127A, given the impracticality of common law resolutions to disputes, one of two outcomes will occur: for the weak, increased inequality and instances of unfair treatment, together with unconscionable conduct by prime contractors; or, for the strong, increased industrial disputation in the absence of any forum for the resolution of disputes.

The second area that I wish to raise is the government's attempt to remove the current provisions which recognise awards covering the payment of superannuation and the significant reduction in the power of the IRC under the proposed bill. The immediate impact of this legislation would see an increase in industrial disputation as workers and employers fight for the ability to determine which fund employee superannuation is directed to. Many employers will want to direct where their employees' superannuation is paid to. Banks will begin approaching employers to get workers to place money into the new retirement savings accounts. Banks may offer a range of inducements to the employers, such as reduced account‐keeping charges on business accounts, reduced overdraft interest rates and the like. Employees will be faced with the decision to accept lower returns, higher administration charges or have a narrower range of value added services or take industrial action to pay into the fund they prefer, not the one directed by the employer.

As the building unions have proved over travelling allowances, many other unions will be forced to conduct wildcat campaigns to protect their members' interests. The removal of these provisions from the act will also disadvantage workers directly as many employers who are currently required to make contributions on a monthly basis will now resort to paying a lump sum by 28 July each year. In the case of the TWU fund employers make monthly payments. This allows workers' accounts to receive compound interest throughout the year on the early contributions.

If the government is successful, a worker will be on a sliding scale of reducing disadvantage to the end of the year. The degree of this disadvantage can be shown by calculating the case of a worker receiving a $1,200 per annum—that is approximately $25 per week—employer SGC contribution. If held for one year—52 weeks—by the employer and not paid monthly, the employee's account balance will be $993.50. If, however, the fund received 12 regular monthly payments of $100, at the end of the year the employee would, at an average return of seven per cent per annum, have in their account $1,034.40. This represents for each worker a financial disadvantage of $40.90 in the first year alone.

To ensure that employers pay employee contributions within 28 days, the TWU superannuation fund, as do other industry funds, employ officers in the field who liaise with employers to make sure that employees' contributions are kept up to date. If superannuation award covered employees become members of funds other than industry funds, it will be difficult to coerce recalcitrant employers to pay employee contributions on a regular monthly basis. The enforcement of regular payments will be even more difficult if the employer has control over where the employee's contributions are placed.

To illustrate this point, take the case of two competing superannuation funds—fund No. 1 and fund No. 2. If superannuation fund No. 1 tries to pressure an employer into regular monthly payments the employer will simply move to superannuation fund No. 2. Therefore, commercial superannuation providers have a financial disincentive to enforce what are current superannuation award standards, and so employees will be disadvantaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tinkering at the edges.
—It might be tinkering at the edges to you, Senator Panizza, but not to the workers in the transport industry.

BREAK.PARA: The next point I wish to make demonstrates that this legislation breaches the Prime Minister's promise that no worker will be worse off. It relates to fee structures. Some super schemes are more suitable for some people than for others. Different schemes have different options regarding investments and, most importantly, different fee structures.

If the government is successful in removing the link between industrial relations and the payment of superannuation, many workers will be worse off as they will be forced to accept a scheme that is not best for them. To illustrate this, let me compare a National Mutual scheme, an Asgard scheme, the TWU super fund and the Brambles super fund plan D. Contribution fee: National Mutual $62.50 a year; Asgard, $62.50; TWU super, nil; Brambles super fund, nil. Asset management fee: National Mutual $375 a year; Asgard, $307.50; TWU, nil; Brambles super fund, nil. Member charge: National Mutual $49; Asgard, $30; TWU super fund, $31.20; Brambles super fund, $160. These fees total as follows: National Mutual $486.50; Asgard, $400; Brambles, $160; TWU super, $31.20. That is not tinkering at the edges, Senator Panizza. That represents being $300 or $400 worse off each year.

If there is any doubt on the other side of the chamber as to whether or not these figures are representative of the industry, I will refer senators to the information available from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission which confirms these figures.

Senators opposite may also believe that the performance of industry funds has been inferior to that of the commercial schemes. Let me put your minds at rest. When asked to compare the relative investment performance, the ISC had the following to say:

A quick comparison of investment performance around seven of the largest industry funds with seven of the larger mastertrusts indicates that in 1994‐95 industry funds returned around 7% to members while mastertrusts returned around 6% (ie, 6% on their balanced portfolio options).

The industry funds data is sourced from ASFA's `Superfunds' magazine (March 1996) while the mastertrust data is sourced from `Mastertrust Analysis' which is a specialist report compiled by Rice Kachor Research.
The consequences of these proposed changes clearly breach the Prime Minister's rock solid guarantee to Australian workers.

The final issue that I wish to address is the impact of section 152 of the bill. This is a nasty, vindictive backdoor attempt to reduce wages and conditions by allowing the state industrial relations system to have primacy over the federal system. How so, some senators on the government side ask? An Australian workplace agreement operates to the exclusion of any award. To quote the bill:
A Federal Award is not binding on any person in respect of an employee who becomes covered by a state employment agreement . . .

What will this mean for workers in Victoria? These are the minimum terms and conditions under Victorian legislation: four weeks paid annual leave for each year worked; one week sick leave for each year worked; an hourly rate of pay equal to the base award rate for the classification of employees as at the time the act commences; 52 weeks unpaid parental and adoption leave, and a right to work part-time for two years after the adoption or birth of a child. That is four conditions—not 18 but four. That is what is going to be happening to workers in the transport industry in Victoria. There is not the 18 conditions that the government claims.

The provision of some minimum wage is of little comfort. For non‐award employees there is no minimum. For employees covered by classification, their guaranteed minimum wage is frozen at the rate applying when the legislation was proclaimed. The legislation also makes extensive provisions as to long service leave, creating a statutory entitlement to 13 weeks paid long service leave after 15 years of continuous employment with one employer.

There are no minimums set with respect to any of the following matters: wages, for the 15 per cent of employees not covered by any award at present; hours of work; spread of hours; overtime; penalty rates for shift work, weekend work or any work on a public holiday; rostered days off; annual leave loading; termination and redundancy; compassionate leave, study leave or leave for jury service; meal and rest breaks; right of entry.

There are a number of other matters which may be included in employment agreements which were illegal in Victoria. Clause 166 permits an employment agreement to allow an employer to require an employee to work for more than five hours without a meal break. Clause 167 permits—incredibly—an employment agreement to contain a provision that enables an employer to fine an employee if the employee's behaviour, attendance or obedience is, in the opinion of the employer, unsatisfactory.

In addition to this, there is no capacity for any industrial dispute to be brought before the Employee Relations Commission of Victoria without the consent of both parties. How should we treat the Prime Minister's core promises to the Australian people? I will tell you: rotten to the core—that's how.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that it is a bit hard to be following such a good speech from Senator Conroy—someone who has real on‐the‐ground experience from the workers perspective. I can understand the imbalance in the power relationship that is so critically embodied in this Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. Next time, let me go before him.

BREAK.PARA: I want to address this legislation from a perspective that has been addressed from time to time. It is one which I think is quite critical to the legislation's success—the legal perspective. Quite a number of concerns have been raised about this legislation, and the concern raised and reflected by Senator Conroy is a critical one.

My concern is that this particular legislation is on very weak ground constitutionally, for a number of reasons. It fails to confront four or five fundamental legal issues. In fact, you could say that this legislation is a gamble constitutionally, and a gamble for which the odds are very long.

I want to address two key areas of concern. The bill is a recipe for protracted legislation and will create an enormous degree of uncertainty for all participants in industrial relations in Australia. Also, given the legal uncertainty, it is a clear recipe for damaging levels of industrial disputation.

Before I go into those areas, I would like to make some preliminary observations. Unfortunately for people in an employment relationship in Australia, for the workers, this is a bill from a government which knows nothing about industrial relations except for its own blind ideology. The government sees the relationship between employer and employee as a simple economic transaction, one in which labour should be bought and sold like any other commodity in the market, according to the price that the market will pay, regardless of the needs of the worker, regardless of any need to have fairness embodied and entrenched in the system.

They can dress up all their views with false platitudes and euphemisms, but this is a centrepiece of their ideology: the market should dictate. This, I must say, is a 19th century view of the work relationship. It is fundamentally flawed. It is a view that the need to be fair to workers is an impediment to the proper working of the labour market.

Such a view, for instance, fails to recognise that the work relationship is one of the most important and critical relationships that we enter into during our lives. It is at the heart of the productive capacity of the nation. For the whole of this century since federation, the notions of fairness and justice in employment in varying forms have been part of the fundamental fabric of our society. Fairness and justice have been embodied in our constitutional system. Fairness and justice at work has been, and continues to be, an essential part of the Australian fabric in the industrial system.
These are the notions that the coalition wants to discard. This bill is not only an attack on workers and their unions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—but an assault on the historical social fabric of this society. It is profoundly—I must say to you, Senator Kemp—an unAustralian piece of legislation when one looks at the nature of the working relationship as embodied in our legal system over and since federation.

BREAK.PARA: The bill ignores the fact that, because of the importance of the work relationship, matters concerning it are frequently litigated at the highest level. Matters quite often go to the High Court. Decisions, like the engineers and boilermakers, which have shaped the fundamental governance in this country, arose from considerations of the Commonwealth industrial power. Matters have gone to the High Court; matters will continue to go to the High Court. This legislation will just ensure that more matters go to the High Court. It will ensure that, while being a bitter pill for workers, it will be a bonanza for lawyers.

Some of the areas of potential challenge to the legislation have been mentioned in the House of Representatives. One area, for instance, is the issue of whether or not to restrict the commission to dealing with only 18 core conditions, and then only to the extent of prescribing minimum conditions. The validity of whether this is properly a law for conciliation and arbitration of industrial disputes has been questioned by quite a number of lawyers. They have argued that to restrict the arbitrator in this way is not properly a law with regard to conciliation and arbitration.

If enacted, this law would have to be seen to be doubtful; and if enacted, it will undoubtedly be subject to challenge—challenge that might bring down the pitiful safety net which is provided by this bill. I am sure that the government is aware of this, and I am sure that the government would not be concerned if the safety net entrenched by this particular provision were to be struck down by the court. This is where deceit comes into this legislation—deceit where protections are based and, in fact, built like a house of cards.

One area in which it is clear that the coalition has problems is with its understanding of the separation of powers. This is not a new problem for coalition conservative politicians in this country, but it is a fundamental problem when one looks at the basis of this legislation and the exercise of arbitral and judicial functions.

A second legal issue which is of concern is that it is quite plain that the jurisdiction given to the Industrial Relations Commission by this bill over unfair dismissals looks remarkably like a judicial function. The bill sets out statutory criteria by which the function is to be worked through, by which the body needs to operate, and by which it is to be judged whether a person is unfairly dismissed. It sets out statutory guidelines for assessing proper remedies. The commission even has scope to order costs in some circumstances.

This is not the usual description of arbitral power. It is settled law that the Industrial Relations Commission cannot exercise judicial power. This means that, when the first employer is aggrieved by being taken to the commission, or is aggrieved by a decision of the commission, that particular employer will have a ready made decision for challenging the commission's jurisdiction. That challenge, once again, inevitably would finish up in the High Court and be decided upon by the High Court, because it goes to the heart of the powers of the commission in this particular case.

So what we have already is a recipe for chaos. We know from experience that a High Court challenge can take a considerable amount of time to be determined. The upshot of all this is that the government would find that its legislation, which flies in the face of established legal precedent, could quite well, in fact—I must say—probably be bowled over by the High Court. As such, all decisions taken by the commission prior to it would also be struck down. So if you are talking about a case that runs for a year or so after the legislation has been put in place, you are talking about a court decision bowling over quite an amount of work done by the commission. This is not a recipe for industrial harmony; this is not a recipe for industrial stability; this is not a recipe that will lay the foundations for economic prosperity.

There are other problems with the bill. Other aspects of potential legal problem emanate from the quite unveiled attack by this legislation on trade unions. This bill is unashamedly a concerted attack on trade unions by the most stridently self-proclaimed anti-union government since federation.
It has been said of the objects of the bill that:
With the exception of meeting family responsibilities, all these objects can be interpreted as anti union.
The same commentator goes on to list some principle provisions of the bill, and then goes on to say:
That list is not exhaustive, but clearly demonstrates the anti union nature of the legislation.
The commentator is not an ACTU official; he is not a Labor or union operative. These are the comments of Nicholas Way, writing in the Business Review Weekly of 3 June.

Every intelligent observer knows, as Peter Reith himself has admitted, that this bill, if enacted, will increase levels of industrial disputation. What is it that drives this government? The anti-union attitude of the Prime Minister and some of his front bench sees a government being prepared to risk legal challenge in order to explore not just the full extent of its constitutional capacity to undermine organised labour, but to go even further—to be more adventurous and to fly in the face of 90 years of legal principle and practice.

That is why this government with its zeal to undermine organised labour intends to remove the requirement that unions need to be capable of being involved in an interstate dispute to become registered. This question of interstate dispute has been very much at the core of legal and constitutional interpretation in industrial matters since Federation. The constitutionality of a provision that undermines this requirement of interstate dispute before a union can be registered has to be of concern.

In the House of Representatives, for instance, it was noted that the ability of unions to become registered has, since the Jumbunna case, been predicated on their ability to engage in an interstate industrial dispute. This is an established factor of industrial law. It will clearly be open to challenge. The government's proposals to move away from this requirement will clearly be open to challenge.

You can go on. There are other factors of this legislation which, as I say, fly in the face of industrial law and industrial practice but, more importantly, fly in the face of constitutional law governing industrial relations in this country. In its desire to undermine organised labour, the government also wishes to allow the creation of enterprise branches. These provisions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, what a terrible thing!

—are the triumph, Senator Kemp, of ideology over good sense. These provisions would oblige unions to have rules that would allow for the creation of branches at a particular site. Senator Kemp says what a terrible thing that is. The union would also have to have rules that give the branches an autonomous fund. This appears to be designed towards two ends: one, obviously, is to reduce the effectiveness of unions by the dispersal of union resources and the second is to allow the potential for enterprise branches in the pockets of individual employers.

PARA.BREAK: The trouble for the government in this area—and I say to you Senator Kemp that this may not be the last time that you will hear these arguments, because we will come back once these provisions are struck down by the court system—is that the provision for an autonomous branch fund is based on requiring unions to have rules for enterprise branches that meet the provisions of schedule 4 of the existing act. They are the provisions addressed at state branches of federal organisa tions that are an attempt to get over a long‐term problem in the industrial arena; that is, to get over the Moore v. Doyle problem of dual incorporation.

BREAK.PARA: They are based on the existing funds and assets of state branches being preserved if the branch moves to a system whereby it forgoes its incorporation under a state industrial system. A mere glance at the provisions of schedule 4 will show that that cannot apply to the creation of new enterprise branches. This will raise enormous problems, I think, in terms of the constitutionality of this section.

We can go on to refer to the government's de‐amalgamation in the proposed division 7A. Again we see ideology driving the government in this area, an ideology to damage organised labour. But once again their zealotry leads them into another area of potential legal challenge. The bill proposes, for instance, to allow the Federal Court to make orders to take the funds and assets of an existing organisation and give them to a new hived off body where a union which has undergone an amalgamation has a division. It is to take into account the assets and liabilities of the hived off body when it first amalgamated and any changes since, and the interests of creditors of the organisation.

I do not think there is any doubt that unions will fight legally any attempt to give their assets to another body, particularly a hived off body. They might challenge whether this is truly a judicial function for a court to perform, given that with enterprise branches the commission appears to be the body responsible for ensuring that the branch gets the proper funds. If it is a judicial function, they might challenge the correctness of any allocation at law. It seems the creditors would also have standing to issue a challenge.

Finally, in terms of another major problem legally, it is quite arguable that any audit to divest a union of its property and deliver it to a body corporate newly created by this bill is the acquisition of property for the purposes of the Commonwealth under the constitution. If that is the case, there will be a requirement, according to the constitution, of compensation on just terms. I think it would be a great irony if in its attempt to undermine trade unions, the government exposes itself to actions as a result of constitutional provisions in this area.

All this leads to a very clear conclusion that the government is taking a constitutional gamble in this area. As a result of these matters we have to accept that there is no guarantee that the government's bill would put in place a legally or constitutionally workable framework for industrial relations in Australia. Given the enormous social and economic importance of the work relationship and the destruction this legislation would cause to it, this is a grotesque gamble with Australia's future. It is a gamble which leads to uncertainty and which leads very clearly to industrial disputation. I must say, Senator Kemp, that I am stunned that you are prepared to go down this route, pursued and driven by zealotry and ideology, and disregarding the national interest.

There are a number of areas which are of legal concern. One that needs to be addressed in this debate is this government's intention to reintroduce into the Australian workplace the spectre of the most wasteful and unnecessary form of industrial action, the demarcation dispute. This is the sort of action the previous government worked hard, with great success, to remove from the industrial landscape. We did it by proper cooperative relationships with the trade union movement, where trade unions elected to restructure, to reduce restrictive work practices and to reduce the number of unions competing for coverage in any calling or on any work site.

This industrial harmony was able to be achieved by creating an industrial environment in which unions were able to rationalise themselves and to move away from the craft‐based unionism of the past to industrial unionism. The then government's greatest contribution was to create an environment that facilitated restructuring and amalgamation by putting the proper combination of legal framework and industrial relations culture in place. Anyone with any experience of industrial relations in Australia will know what an important improvement it was in terms of industrial relations in the area of demarcation disputes during the 1980s and 1990s.

What is most incomprehensible is that this bill contains not just one but a raft of provisions designed to cause proliferation of unions and the competition of unions for membership. The bill, for instance, will remove the conveniently belong test for the registration of new unions. What will this do? This is a test designed to ensure that new unions will not be formed that will end in damaging disputes between unions over membership in a particular area. It is a rule that has worked successfully because it has been flexible enough to allow the registration of a new union on occasions when existing unions have failed to properly represent a group of workers.
This is the first government ever to believe it is a good idea to change this conveniently belong provision. The bill provides for the establishment of enterprise branches of unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Terrible.

—You shake your head and you say terrible, in your naive ignorance of industrial relations, Senator Kemp. What will happen, if this particular bill gets up, is the unions that we are talking about, the enterprise branches, will become known very quickly as bosses' unions. In any workplace, you will find decent trade unionists who will find it enormously difficult to belong to these branches. As such, even if 70 per cent of people at a particular work site are part of a bosses' union, the other people will have a capacity to want to belong to another industrial organisation. What you will do with this particular legislation is fragment industrial representation in individual workplaces. If you reckon that is going to lead to industrial harmony, Senator Kemp, it would confirm in me all the views that I had about your awareness of industrial relations. It is a recipe for industrial dislocation in every workplace in this country.
—It is a recipe for higher wages and that is what you do not like.

—You might say that it is a recipe for higher wages, but when you undermine the capacity of workers to negotiate and to bargain together, when you put them in the employer‐employee relationship which was a feature of industrial law before the turn of the century, when you put them in that master and slave relationship without effective representation, it is a recipe for undermining wages. You do not want flexibility up; you want flexibility down. I must say that this legislation provides all the flexibility down without any constitutional guarantee for the protections that you say are part of this legislation.

BREAK.PARA: This is an enormous gamble because the protections in this legislation are constitutionally shonky: they would not stand up constitutionally and they constitutionally fly in the face of the history of constitutional law in this country since Federation. You, in your blind ignorance, can shake your head and say, `That's not on', but you have absolutely no guarantee to Australian workers, who, if this bill is passed, will find that the protections offered to them by this legislation could very well be struck out in the court system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has assured us that the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is the answer to unemployment in this country. I only wish it was the case. But, as the former Reserve Bank Governor Bernie Fraser said last month, if you repeat these things often enough, you can fool some people into believing them for a time. The simple fact is the Prime Minister is wrong. Bernie Fraser, his successor Ian Macfarlane and prominent economist Dr Bob Gregory have all poured scorn on the Prime Minister's assertion.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to explore two important aspects of the bill and their impact on one of the most disadvantaged and most unemployment prone parts of the labour market—young Australians. The bill before us proposes two things to solve youth unemployment. Firstly, it proposes to abolish the current legislative phase‐out of junior rates of pay and, basically, preserve forever discrimination against young workers simply because they are young. Secondly, this bill provides the legislative underpinning of the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system, MAATS, the government's much vaunted new labour market training program for young people specifically.

Both of these proposals, in my view, are inadequate and, in the case of junior rates of pay, quite offensive. To say that young people can only keep their jobs if they are paid half the wages of adults for doing the same types of work is demeaning. To say that the MAATS scheme, with its $20 million of extra places a year, will somehow make up for the $1 billion worth of labour market and training programs that have been cut over the next two years simply defies logic.

Firstly, let me deal with junior rates of pay. Three years ago, the Australian Democrats, as many of the honourable senators here would know, supported the insertion of a provision into the Industrial Relations Act, section 90AB, declaring discrimination on the basis of age illegal. We provided an exemption of four years, until June 1997, to allow the parties to develop a new replacement wages system for junior rates.

It was our view then, and it is our view today, that, just because someone is 16, 17 or even 20 and doing the same work side by side with someone who is older, they should not automatically be paid 50 per cent of those wages. That is blatant discrimination and shows blatant disregard for the principle of equal work for equal pay.

The government is telling us and some employers have told us that junior rates are necessary to ensure that young people have employment prospects and that, if we get rid of them, more young people will be out of work, contributing to the 27 per cent youth unemployment level that we currently have. I still find it very difficult that people persist with this notion that there is some causal connection between lower wage rates for young people and increased employment opportunities. In fact, we have had little evidence provided to us that supports this assertion other than the prejudice of some employers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—In fact, Senator Kemp, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, you will find that most evidence is to the contrary. There is a very authoritative study by Princeton University academics, David Card and Alan Kreuger, of minimum wage adjustment in the United States showing that an increase in the minimum wage has not led to unemployment. Studies such as this must frustrate a lot of economists and certainly, I suggest, a lot of senators, because they show that the labour market is very different from the market of apples and oranges. In fact, the labour market constantly defies economic models and economic theories on how it should behave, and the youth market is a classic example.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen research recently by the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, AYPAC, showing that, in the last two decades, wages for young people have fallen in real terms in this country, yet youth unemployment has risen. Indeed, the number of full‐time jobs filled by young people is static in a growing economy. But the contrariness of the youth employment market gets worse. Of course, in the 1970s and still today, the principal substitute for young people in the labour force has been married women. The equal pay case of the early 1970s, which increased wages for married women, was amid all sorts of doom and gloom forecasts that this increase in wage levels would somehow kill the employment prospects of married women.

Since then, the employment rates of married women have increased exponentially. However, the employment of young people has not. The only piece of research that I have seen in support of retaining youth wages was a survey of members conducted by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Even this survey showed that the principal determinant employers act on in deciding whether or not to employ a young person is not youth wages but the ability to train their own workers from scratch. In short, the proponents of retaining youth wages have not made out a very strong case.

The impact of phasing out junior rates has been exaggerated. But I also understand the need to ensure there is adequate education of employers as well as employees to accompany the phasing out of such wage rates. For three years the Industrial Relations Commission has conducted a junior rates test case to encourage the parties to replace junior rates with a non-discriminatory wage system. Unfortunately, I find that process has been disappointing.

The best that the parties have been able to come up with so far has been to take junior rates in the retail industry, knock out all reference to age and replace it with a reference to a combination of schooling and years since that person had left school which, for all intents and purposes, meant the same thing as age based discrimination. This system is still indirect discrimination. It would still leave young school leavers, working side by side with older workers, being paid, I think, roughly 45 per cent less than their adult counterparts for no good reason. This simply is not good enough. We need to address the fact that it is the firm view in some employers' minds that young people are somehow worth less than older workers. That can only be done through better research and better information.

The appropriate organisation to look into some of these issues and look at the discrimination argument versus the employment argument is the Industrial Relations Commission. Of course experience tells us that even the IRC needs a bit of a push along to pursue some issues. Indeed, the Democrats actually initiated the carers' leave case thanks to amendments we moved in this chamber years ago. The Democrats are opposed to the continuation of junior rates. We believe the parliament must amend this bill to make it clear that junior rates have to go. I will specifically address some of those amendments in the committee stage.

This brings me to MAATS. What has become increasingly clear over the past two decades has been that the youth market is dysfunctional. Technological and industrial change has wiped out thousands of jobs formerly occupied by young people—jobs which often lead to white and blue collar employment. The growth of retail and fast food industries has created other jobs but these have tended to be casual employment rather than full‐time employment, which has disappeared. This radical change in the youth employment market has seen a large rise in youth unemployment levels and a much larger proportion of young people choosing to stay in education, although, under the government's current budget changes, I am not sure they are offering much incentive for young people to stay in or pursue education at whatever level.

In 1992, the Australian Democrats were so concerned about the dysfunctional nature of the youth labour market and the failure of government policy to deal with this that we proposed a youth guarantee—that is, that young people should be guaranteed a place in either education or training or employment by the government. As we know today, in 1994 the former Labor government picked up this idea—they thought it was so good—as part of their Working Nation package.

Unfortunately, this government seeks to cut back on those programs. Despite rising unemployment, 670,000 job program places will be cut to 440,000. The government has assured us that places will only be cut from those programs that are not working. Yet the program with the highest success rate—I believe around 90 per cent record of young people in unsubsidised employment, the Australian traineeship system—has been capped at 34,000 places. So just when employers are finally beginning to welcome traineeships, the growth of this vital program has been cut.

It is in this environment that the government has unveiled MAATS. The Democrats support MAATS in principle, but we have a number of concerns as to how it will work. These concerns have been exacerbated by the almost complete lack of policy detail that surrounds this whole proposal. Foremost among our concerns is that under MAATS some young people will be financially disadvantaged. Only paying young people for the time they spend in productive work as opposed to training means that in many cases wages under MAATS will be lower than they are currently and in some cases wages under MAATS will actually fall to levels which are below the current level of unemployment benefits.

The government has promised that it will pay a top‐up wage to young people who undertake the MAATS apprenticeships and traineeships, but I am yet to be convinced that this payment will go anywhere near towards providing young people with the means to sustain a reasonable living standard. As far as I can see, even through the estimates committee process, there are no guarantees to ensure that this top‐up will be passed on to the employee by their employers.

The Democrats are also yet to be convinced that training and qualifications received under MAATS, with all its flexibility, will be transportable and nationally consistent. This is one area of MAATS that we will be watching very closely. The Democrats will only support MAATS if it results in real jobs and real benefits for young Australians. Our primary purpose, as details of the MAATS proposal continue to unfold—at least I think they are beginning to unfold—will be to protect and further the interests of young Australians.

The operation of the MAATS system or MAATS proposal is contingent upon the passage of the workplace relations bill. This is because an essential part of MAATS is to allow individual agreements between trainees and their employers; that is, to modify the mix of training and work within apprenticeships and traineeships.

Unfortunately, flexibility is often a one‐way street and often the employers' way. What bargaining strength does a young person have to negotiate flexibility? What skills will they have to stand up for their rights against an employer? None. Yet the government's proposal for AWAs assumes that young people can handle such negotiations and that if there was a problem young people would simply trot off to the Employment Advocate who will sort it out for them.

It ignores the basic principle that if a person is in such a disadvantaged bargaining position that they basically agree to an AWA under duress they are unlikely to have the confidence to complain about that AWA afterwards. The Democrats believe that certified agreements and AWAs, particularly those involving young people, must be scrutinised before they are approved.

BREAK.PARA: The proposal to discount wages for apprenticeships and trainees based on an increase in training time has the potential to offer great harm as well as great benefit for employees—great benefit if young people are able to accelerate their training and enter full trade rates earlier, but great harm if they end up with insufficient income to live while they are doing so.

The government has proposed a top-up allowance based on the lowest level of the national training wage award. There is strong argument—and I believe this very strongly—that these rates are far too low. Of more concern to us also is that the allowance is not related to competency. Take, for example, the case of a second‐year apprentice in the metal trades. The most likely change in work-training mix would see training increased from the equivalent of one day a week to two days a week. For a metal trades apprentice, having completed the equivalent of a year's training, under the government's proposal they would end up being paid exactly the same as a first‐year apprentice, despite the intensive training.

The top-up of $195 per week is well below the award second-year rate of $229 per week. We believe this is hardly an incentive for young people to engage in accelerated training. When you have some employers who are already complaining or concerned about the difficulty in finding young people to fill training and apprenticeship places in some industries, we need to be concerned about the incentive effect of any changes to wage rates in particular.

We are also of the firm view that training arrangements should not be approved unless they are in the best interests of the trainees. It is their interests, not the interests of employers, that must be paramount. From that point of view, we oppose the suggestion that training arrangements in AWAs could be approved by people who are not competent to do so, by local employment councils synonymous with local chambers of commerce, as I believe has been suggested by some.

Training arrangements must be consistent with the national training framework and the national training standards as enforced by state training authorities, industry training boards and other such bodies. These protections—the guarantee of a fair deal on wages and conditions, and the guarantee of a bona fide national accredited training—must be provided if the MAATS system is going to pass the Senate. The Democrats will deal with these issues in more detail in the committee stage of the bill.

In conclusion, the Democrats believe that this bill as it stands provides little advances for our troubled youth employment market, contrary to the great faith that Senator Chapman was showing earlier for the workplaces relations bill to solve youth unemployment in this country. Most worryingly, I think this bill returns to the dark old ages of discrimination simply on the basis of age. Exploiting young people's skills, their talents and their labour is something that I will never vote for. I will always oppose discrimination on the basis of age and I will always oppose the exploitation of young people.
At this stage I believe that this bill fails the balance between fairness and economic advancement. It will need significant amendments to attract my support or, indeed, the support of my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I start in this debate on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 by saying that I am a proud member of a union. I have been a member of a union since the day I started employment. To restrict people's access to trade union membership is an infringement of their freedom to associate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have gained a lot of value out of being a member of a trade union, particularly in nursing where the union was able to provide us with coverage if we needed to appear in a court of law. That did happen while I was doing my training. One of our patients who had been suffering from acute depression jumped off a balcony and died. Colleagues of mine were required to attend a coroner's court. They were able to obtain legal representation through the support and the encouragement of the union. It seems to me that any nurse who does not want to be in the union needs his or her brains brushed for that particular reason, if no other.

This bill is a fundamental attack on the rights of workers in this country. It erodes the three pillars which have protected workers in Australia for decades. It erodes the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as the independent umpire. It erodes the role of the award system and it erodes the right to collectively bargain for Australia and Australians.

It is an unprecedented attack which removes virtually all power or equality that employees have in their relationship with employers. It is founded on the flawed premise that workers and bosses are equal parties in a relationship. This is not the case. Nothing could be further from the truth. When a prospective employee goes for an interview, they are in need of a job or want a job. They want income. When the employer, on the other hand, enters into the agreement or the bargaining, more often than not there are more people vying for the position than there are positions available.

I heard recently of a case where 40 positions for apprentices were advertised and there were 1,900 applications. Who has got the equality there? It certainly is not one of the 1,900 who are trying to get 40 places. One thousand nine hundred does not go into 40. One thousand nine hundred leaves 1,860 without any job. It leaves them highly dependent upon unemployment benefits.

The bill also assumes that the signed contract between the employer and the employee is just like any other contract. But it is not. Employees are not bags of cement, they are not computers, they are not inanimate objects without any feeling. They are people with feelings, with needs and with the need to support themselves and their families. The current government seems to have forgotten that.

Whilst there is room for negotiation of workplace agreements, the worker must be protected. That is not to say that every boss is out to get their workers, to rip them off and to treat them badly but, without legislation to protect employees, they are at the mercy of unscrupulous employers. Interestingly, the converse can be true too, where you have a powerful group of people who are in a position to actually attempt to exploit the employer. A number of employers raised that concern during the inquiry that was undertaken by the Senate committee.

The previous Labor government worked towards a flexible system of workplace relations to take into account differences between different work situations. Foremost in our minds was always the concept of fairness—fairness to workers and their families as well as fairness to employers and consideration for their situation. This government is taking away this fairness.

I will go back to expanding on why people are not equal when they are in that situation. The government expects people who are new to the work force to make a secret deal with their boss so that nobody else from the plant or the workplace knows what anybody else is being paid. You expect them to make a secret deal. Can you tell me how a woman who has been out of the workplace for five or 10 years while raising a family or a young person coming into the workplace for the first time is in any position of power to have equality? It is quite obvious that they are not.

I thought all legal contracts had to be signed where there was full understanding of the ramifications of everything, where everything had to be explained to them. But it strikes me that this legislation leaves a lot of people vulnerable to signing legal documents that they do not understand. They have not been in the position of equality to actually discuss and negotiate the documents in a proper and fit manner. I wonder what is actually going to happen.

Of course, there is nowhere that they can go to challenge this, because they are gutting the Industrial Relations Commission. If the boss says, `No, I'm not changing anything,' they are required to take their complaints and their challenges through the common law courts. How many people at age 18 or 19 have the capacity or the ability—firstly, the intellect and the courage and, secondly, the finances—to take something through the federal courts?

What is the length of time that it is going to take to get it through? What is the impact going to be with the tightening up, as we are seeing Senator Newman doing with tightening up, on the dole bludgers? Are people who are potentially being ripped off by an employment contract and who are saying, `No, that's not correct,' and refusing the job going to be told they have to wait 12 weeks to get unemployment benefits? That is what you are doing. You are putting pressure on people to not negotiate out a legitimate settlement and a legitimate wage. With the complementary social security legislation, you are forcing people to take what is offered; in other words, like it or lump it. That is something that is of grave concern to me, and I think it should be of grave concern to every thinking and caring person in this country.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission has played a pivotal role in maintaining this fairness and seeing that employees are treated respectfully and receive fair pay and conditions. This government will gut the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and turn it into a toothless tiger through 36 limitations to the commission's powers. For example, the IRC will no longer have general jurisdiction to settle industrial disputes by arbitration. This function will be extremely limited. As I have said earlier, it can leave the employees vulnerable and it can leave the employers vulnerable. We only ever hear from the government, those opposite, about what terrible things the unions and the employees will have done; we hear nothing about their concern for the employers.

The IRC will no longer have the power to review workplace agreements, so nobody will be there to arbitrate the agreement that has been made. If it is unfair, it will have to be taken up and fought in the common law courts. We already know what the backlog of court cases is like, and this will just add to it.

We know that the people on the bench of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission are people who are skilled and expert in industrial relations matters. They have a full understanding of the awards. They have a full understanding of the issues involved because they often have a background in that area, either from the employer or the employee situation, prior to going to the bench.

BREAK.PARA: But that expertise and those skills and knowledge will be lost when you could end up in a court where the presiding officer is, in fact, someone whose area of expertise may well have been commercial law or copyright or something that is totally unrelated to industrial relations. I do not mean that with any disrespect for those who sit upon the bench. I have nothing but the utmost respect for them. But, as with most professions, people do specialise. I think it is only right that, in this situation, people who have industrial relations type problems should be able to take their cases quickly to a jurisdiction where the people oversighting the case have expertise and knowledge in the area.

The IRC will no longer have power to deal with claims for strike pay, even when it feels the strike was justified. The IRC will no longer be able to set actual rates of pay or keep awards up with inflation. There is one group that I am particularly concerned about that will be affected by this legislation, and that is women.

During the Senate Economics References Committee's considerations of this bill, women's groups expressed three major concerns: that the removal of the commission's powers to ensure equal remuneration would result in further inequalities in pay and conditions for women; that the proposed arrangements for workplace bargaining would disadvantage women; and that the deregulation of part-time work—in particular, the removal of minimum and maximum hours—would disadvantage women who form the bulk of this sector of the work force.

I will deal with these three points first. Firstly, the slow advancement towards equal pay for women, particularly in over‐award payments, has not just been due to the laws of supply and demand or the beneficence of employers. It certainly will not come about if these matters are left solely up to the market and market forces. Women have slowly moved towards equal pay through the efforts of women's groups and the enacting and enforcing of legislation through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Indeed, the previous government introduced new equal remuneration provisions in part VIA of the act which gave the commission the ability to remedy instances of discriminatory over‐award payments. That is where women have been particularly disadvantaged in their payments. It is not the award payment; it is the over‐award payments—the extras that get added to remuneration packages—that are not going to remain in the act. We are also concerned because removing the Industrial Relations Commission's powers in this regard will be a huge step backwards in the fight for equal pay for equal work.

Secondly, women are traditionally in a disadvantaged position in the work force. They are often not employed full time and they have little bargaining experience or they may have a host of situations where their bargaining power is at a minimum. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1966 will further disadvantage women through the extension of workplace bargaining and the removal of the protection of the Industrial Relations Commission.

Thirdly, there are many more women than men involved in part‐time and casual work: 41 per cent of the female work force is employed on a part‐time basis and 75 per cent of part‐time workers are women. This bill will remove the minimum and maximum hours that part‐time employees can work. The setting of minimum hours for part‐time employees was designed to ensure that they had reasonable chances to work, as well as providing a steady income and a similar pay packet from week to week. We now see the situation where women are not sure from one week to the next what their hours of work are going to be. It will make budgeting extremely difficult. If women receive very small remunerations for their work, it will also make it very difficult if they are able to and eligible to apply for social security benefits. This will be particularly so if we see it combined with the abolition in the budget of the ability of workers to work and earn up to $1,000 in a year and to have those earning credits there if they wish to apply for social security benefits.

When you combine this bill with the changes that it was announced during the budget were going to take place to some of the social security programs, you see how draconian and how evil and mean‐spirited this government is being to people who have to find employment and work part time. As I have mentioned, the lack of consistent rostering schedules is crucial. Women who work part time are often those with families and who are trying to juggle child care and child rearing with their own needs and those of their spouses and their occupations. It means that they do not have a great deal of flexibility and, if they do not know what hours they are going to be working from week to the next, they will have even less flexibility and even less ability to plan.

Under the current system there is a ratio of full‐ to part‐time workers, and this must be maintained. This legislation will remove that ratio and increase the number of part‐time workers that can be employed. This will especially disadvantage women, as it will remove opportunities to move into a full‐time career; by moving into a full‐time career you actually can get onto a career path. But, again, this government does not seem to care about those sorts of issues or those sorts of needs.

Casual workers, of course, will not be eligible for parental leave. Women make up the majority of the casual work force and again it is obvious that they are going to be further disadvantaged. It is quite clear that the `rock solid' guarantee of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that no workers will be worse off is not applicable to women. It is obvious that the conservatives want to say that women should be at home doing whatever they want them to do there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the coalition's Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill is an outstanding piece of legislation, representing a major overhauling, simplification and streamlining of a very complex area of industrial relations in Australia.
