For you to come to this debate with the suggestion that we are going to rip the moral standing away from the Australian people and the rights of workers leads me to say to you: look at your own economic record and, for that matter, look at the moral record of the previous government. I would pitch the moral standing of our Prime Minister, John Howard, before the Australian public against your two previous prime ministers any time.

So, Senator Cooney, I just have to take that suggestion up because in another place for another debate what you were saying was very good, and I could not agree more with it, but to try to implant that in this industrial relations debate is either a trick—which you are so very good at performing—or you are sadly misguided.

For over a decade now, the coalition has been pushing and debating for structural changes within the existing industrial relations system. We believe that, until the existing structure of setting wages and work conditions is changed, inroads into our intolerable rates of unemployment will not be made. This legislation is not for the single benefit of employers; rather the expected benefits will be for the employers and the employees alike and it follows for the nation as a whole. That is very much unlike what motivated the previous government's introduction of their industrial relations legislation in those now infamous words by the ACTU chief Jennie George—and they will always remind us of the sentiments of the previous legislation—when she said on radio soon after the 1993 election:
What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election in March and this bill is a payback for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of the election campaign.

The results since then have been quite obvious. It was a favoured piece of legislation. In stark contrast, we pledge that this legislation is to the benefit of the employer and the employee and that no worker will be worse off through these reforms. In fact, these reforms are necessary to lift and to hold the Australian standard of living for decades to come.

Having achieved government, with the industrial relations reform bill as one of our key policies, the workplace relations bill fulfils the long‐term commitment that we made to the Australian people. The No. 1 principle of the legislation is to deliver choice into the workplace; therefore, it follows that flexibility will be introduced into the now rigid system. Under this particular bill, employers and employees will have a choice of remaining on the award or taking advantage of the new enterprise bargaining arrangements.

To that end, there will be two choices within those enterprise bargaining arrangements: firstly, what is called the certified agreements which are no more than collective enterprise agreements covering the employees in the particular business. Alternatively, the other choice is of an agreement that is individually based, so‐called in the legislation as Australian workplace agreements. In tandem with these three choices, the government is committed to providing a safety net for the wages and conditions of employees under these three streams.

There will be some 18 subject areas to be covered that have been tenets of previous awards and will remain so under the certified agreements or the workplace agreements. I will run through some of them, so people are aware that we are not stripping away any of the existing award achievements and conditions—for example, overtime, casual and shift work loadings, allowances, public holidays, long service leave, annual leave, bonuses, ordinary time hours of work and times within which they are performed, and classification of employees.

Further to this, the award conditions safety net has a secondary advantage of simplifying the awards and the agreements. It should be noted that the award simplification was supported in the previous government's Working Nation document when the then Prime Minister said:
The Government believes that enterprise bargaining should be underpinned by minimum standards of wages and conditions provided through the wage system.

He went on to specify some 10 core provisions for awards as against our 18. Of course, history shows that the Labor government were forced to buckle under the pressure of the ACTU and those principles never saw the light of day.

Contrary to the perceptions given by the opposition, the Industrial Relations Commission keeps a major role. All certified agreements with or without union participation must be approved by the Industrial Relations Commission. Further, as is the case now, award variations must also be approved by the Industrial Relations Commission. It is only in the case of workplace agreements that the Industrial Relations Commission's role is taken up by the Employment Advocate away from the Industrial Relations Commission and the courts, having the task to oversee the individually based contracts—being an independent umpire.

Again, this reflects the choice principle. The parties have the choice of the Industrial Relations Commission or the Employment Advocate. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) in the other house, in his second reading speech, said:

If anyone has any doubts about the need for genuine reform of our industrial relations institutions and arrangements, they need go no further than the latest AB statistics which show an intolerable rate of unemployment, at 8.9%—
from this week's figures, that is 8.7 per cent—
and a disgraceful 27.8% for our youth.

It is in this area, youth unemployment, that attention is most needed and it is also in this area that the government and the opposition parties most differ, both philosophically and practically. For it was the previous government that had written into the legislation to abolish junior rates by June 1997. In contrast, this legislation before the Senate maintains age based junior rates.

Currently, many workers aged between 15 and 20 years are employed on junior wages. For example, in the retail industry, typical junior wages for 18‐year‐olds are 70 per cent of adult rates and, for 17‐year‐olds, they are some 60 per cent of adult rates.

The surest way to handicap a young person in obtaining employment where junior wages are a part of the awards—they are not part of every award—is to increase the employer's costs to the extent that there is no difference between the wages of an experienced, adult employee and those of an inexperienced, junior employee. That is just commonsense and a fact of life in the workplace.

While the abolition of junior rates would have the obvious detrimental effect on youth unemployment, nothing has had a more retarding effect on employment than the absurd unfair dismissal laws. While the laws produced many laughable judgments from the Industrial Relations Commission, they became a very serious factor at the last federal election. That issue ranked high on the list of reasons business, particularly small business, supported the coalition en masse. The proposed changes to these laws have been eagerly awaited by small business.

PARA.BREAK: The legislation, while protecting the rights of employees that have been unfairly dismissed, will nevertheless take out the com plexity and the legalistic nature of the provisions and check against those frivolous and often malicious claims which have been the hallmark of the existing system. Past judgments have simply put too much weight on the procedural fairness factor; namely, as employers would well know, the recording of warnings 1, 2 and 3, then a bit of counselling, a possible retraining and even relocation. Under this government's proposal, procedural fairness will remain a factor but it will not now be the sole factor before the courts. All the circumstances surrounding a dismissal must now be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The reforms mentioned have been long awaited, particularly by Australia's rural and regional areas. These areas have been burdened by higher than average unemployment rates and costly workplace structures. As it is well known, business in the rural and regional areas is predominantly made up of small businesses. Under the existing system they have been handicapped from forming workplace agreements that are peculiar to their regions and, quite frankly, are central to their viability. Further, small businesses have had to endure the absurd unfair dismissal laws, which are magnified in the rural areas because they are operating on a lesser profit margin, given that they are linked to the very poor state of the rural economy.

I single out the meat industry, which has suffered under decades of industrial disruption and archaic and costly work practices. The blame in this particular case can be sheeted right home solely to the militant unions. The state of the meat processing industry today rivals the disgraceful standard of our waterfront. Over the decade, thousands of jobs have been lost due to abattoirs being forced to close, particularly in my state of Victoria. As a result, now some 80 per cent of the meat processing companies are owned by foreign interests.

The Industry Commission inquired into the meat industry and found the processing sector to be in urgent need of reform. The commission estimated that reforms to the sector would deliver over a billion dollars a year. Although the problems associated are labour related, the issue is not the rate of pay but the rate of output per unit of wage, better known as productivity.

Another report, from Booz Allen Hamilton, shows the reality of the problem. On a per kilo, finished weight basis, the costs of our meat processors are uncompetitive. These figures will show that. To process one kilo of meat it costs in Australia 113c; in Argentina, 105c; in New Zealand, 72c; and in the United States, 41c. The obvious consequences, particularly from the United States, flowed.

In 1994 the Sizzler restaurant chain decided to import United States beef as it was, quite simply, as those figures show, cheaper to do so. Even with the American beef being 60 per cent more expensive than our beef at the farm gate, it was cheaper to purchase from the American farmer, put it through their abattoirs, move it through their wharves, ship it across the Pacific, put it through our wharves—that would have been a great difficulty—pass our meat inspectors and distribute it in the Sizzler chain of restaurants. It was still cheaper than just going down the road and picking a slab of Australian beef from our abattoirs.

For further evidence of the non-viability of our abattoirs or meat processing sector, look at live cattle exports to Asia. Selling live cattle to Asia is more profitable than it is to process in Australia. It is a poor indictment of our processing sector if processing cattle in Australia does not value add. In fact, it subtracts value. These are jobs that have been lost and will probably never be won back. It is expected that the workplace relations bill will bring significant reforms to this particular sector. Moreover, this is really the testing ground for the success of this bill.

The bill before the Senate, while a key reform of this government, is but only one part of our strategy—the balanced budget is the other part—to transform the Australian economy into a world-class, competitive economy. That must ultimately improve the employment level, which is the main desire of every household in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Kernot indicated in her speech this week, the Democrats regard the bill as set out before us as unsupportable in its present form. It is our view that if this bill were to pass the Senate it would have to be substantially amended. Throughout the debate on this bill and throughout the election campaign, the Democrats have restated our support for a strong award system and a strong independent umpire, in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to ensure that workers who are at a disadvantage in the labour market are adequately protected.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Victorian I can speak with first‐hand experience of the full brunt of the Liberal‐National Party reform agenda since the election of the Kennett government in 1992. I concede that this bill is not as radical as the Victorian legislation, but it is well on the way down the same track. I note that the major business backers of the bill—the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Business Council of Australia—have both said that the bill does not go far enough, suggesting pressure will continue for further so-called reform in later years.

The bill contains some provisions which are common to Victoria. The most obvious similarity is that the proposed Australian workplace agreements would take effect from the day they are signed and would not be vetted by the Industrial Commission. This feature is found in the Victorian system but it is not found in any other state in Australia. Even the conservative governments of New South Wales, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia required some element of vetting before agreements took place.

The President of the Victorian Employee Relations Commission, Susan Zeitz, has been very critical of this lack of vetting in her annual reports. She has expressed concern that many employees simply assume that because an agreement has been lodged with the ERC, it has been approved by that body. Many workers would assume the same thing with those unvetted Australian workplace agreements.

PARA.BREAK: The Victorian system provides only a minimal number of minimum conditions for agreements. Whilst the proposed AWA stream would have a few more, a range of important issues would not be protected. But, more importantly, employers, particularly in Vic toria, would be able to opt out of federal awards into state employment agreements under section 152. This means that in the case of Victoria, despite all the publicity attached to the so-called safeguards of the AWAs, Victorian employers would be able to get individual employment agreements under Jeff Kennett's legislation and thus avoid a federal award. This would reverse the flight of hundreds of thousands of Victorian workers from the Victorian to the federal system and expose workers in my state to widespread exploitation. Information about the nature of Victorian employment agreements is scanty because agreements are not made public. Some of this information did come through the Senate committee. However, it is worth highlighting some of that evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: In the child‐care industry one of the employer organisations circulated an employment agreement to its members which undermined a wide range of employment conditions without adequate compensation. According to the union, the agreement proposed to: reduce casual loadings from 25 to 20 per cent; increase the amount of overtime needed to attract double time from two to three hours; reduce the number of public holidays; abolish the annual leave loading; reduce sick leave from 91 hours a year to just 36 hours; and require employees to supply their own uniforms. Great pressure was put on employees to sign. We need to be mindful that employment in this industry is neither permanent nor easy to come by. The employer association refused to discuss the agreement with the unions and strenuously opposed efforts by them to get an interim federal award reflecting the old state award.

Young workers have been particularly vulnerable. Many work in the hospitality industry and they are easily `punished' for refusing to sign agreements by seeing their rostered casual hours reduced. The Bendigo Trades Hall Council highlighted the problems it had in getting Jardine's Restaurants, the owners of Pizza Hut and Sizzler, to provide a decent agreement for young people. Young people were not even able to take the agreement home for their parents to check. Those who refused to sign had their hours cut. The Sizzler agreement contained lots of progressive conditions such as requiring workers to work six hours, and even double shifts without any break. The union was eventually able to get a federal award for Pizza Hut and a federal certified agreement for Sizzler, but only after an awful lot of young workers were hurt in that process.

Workers in country Victoria, because of high unemployment and low levels of awareness of their rights, are particularly vulnerable. The Sunraysia Trades and Labour Council gave evidence of some of the contracts in its area, such as the bread carter who paid a grand sum of $9.50 per hour for work performed at any time of the day or night, including weekends and public holidays—in fact, whenever the employer wanted.

A major loser in the Victorian system has been women, reflecting their weak bargaining position. An extensive study of 116 Victorian agreements by the national pay equity coalition showed that only 19 per cent of agreements included a wage rise, even though 34 per cent of agreements reduced overtime loading, 26 per cent reduced shift work penalties and a whopping 64 per cent abolished weekend penalty rates.

In 1992 the Democrats supported the amendment of the Industrial Relations Act to insert the fast‐track provisions to allow Victorian workers to transfer from the state to the federal system. This provision has prevented much widespread exploitation of Victorian workers.

One group which has had the most difficulty with the Victorian system has been the employees of the state government itself. Victorian teachers received no wage rise for the first few years of the Kennett government. What rises were offered were only available if they agreed to sign individual agreements. These agreements had the potential to undermine the professional standards of the teaching profession. Eventually the Australian Education Union was forced to seek a federal award and to arbitrate the rates under that award. This is the only way they had to maintain the paid rates nature of their industry.

BREAK.PARA: For public sector workers paid rates awards are very important. Paid rates awards ensure that governments cannot play favourites between employees. Paid raids awards ensure that teachers in poor schools, for instance, do not end up being paid less than teachers in rich schools. Paid rates awards ensure that government ministers, in their quest to cut the so-called fat from bureaucracy, cannot unilaterally withdraw established and important employment conditions. Most importantly, paid rates awards, because they are capable of being arbitrated, give employees in the public sector an important protection against the omnipotent legal power of the state. It is a nonsense to suggest that an individual teacher, nurse or police officer can walk in and negotiate on equal terms with the state government.

This inequality of the bargaining process has been reflected in the Victorian government's employment contracts which have been presented on very much a take or leave it basis. Even if government workers choose to take industrial action against their employer, it is rarely effective because of the massive legal and financial resources of the government. Industrial issues rapidly become interwoven with political agendas, and it becomes impossible for good industrial practice to be discussed.

The Democrats believe that government workers must retain the ability to have their paid rates awards established by arbitration where governments refuse to reach appropriate agreements with them. The experience of the refusal of the Victorian government to bargain with its workers on a collective basis highlights this absolute necessity.

The appalling treatment meted out to the State Public Services Federation in Victoria over the past four years, the fights against its efforts to obtain a federal award, the refusal of the Victorian government to agree to voluntary arbitration on issues in the Victorian Employee Relations Commission, the refusal to even recognise that the union represents its members and, most importantly, the refusal to bargain over wages and conditions are the strongest arguments possible for the retention of paid rates awards. Bargaining is clearly not working.

The workplace relations bill fails to provide for paid rates awards or arbitration of paid rates conditions. It allows arbitrated federal awards to be undermined by state employment agreements. In short, it fails to protect adequately government employees.

There remains strong support for the award system in Victoria. The Victorian Council of Social Services and the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties both highlighted the importance of the award system and the AIRC in protecting the rights of the disadvantaged. Employer groups, too, were supportive. The Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce in its evidence strongly supported the retention of the award system, arguing that many small employers preferred the certainty of the award system to the difficulties of enterprise bargaining.

The Australian Road Transport Industry Association reported a similar line. America's Professor Joe Isaac, who completed a major study of small business attitudes to awards a few years ago, reported that the vast majority of small businesses were generally satisfied with the award system. Interestingly, major employer organisations have reported that copies of the lapsed Victorian awards are still best sellers as small businesses prefer a simple statement of what they should pay in wages and conditions to the hard work of starting from scratch.

What has not been recognised by the government in drafting this bill is the complexity and diversity of jobs and employment conditions that exist in this country. All senators in this place would have received letters from workers concerned about losing hard‐won conditions. But I think some of the most compelling that I have received have been from workers in the performing arts.
A Victorian stunt actor and safety supervisor in film and television, one of the very few women in this hazardous side of the industry, writes:

Our safety code was first conceived after a fatal accident during the filming of the Matlock Police television series . . . and finally brought in after another fatality on the feature film Midnight Spares in the early eighties.

Since then the industry, via the Safety Code has trained and graded stunt performers. If the award preference clauses become unlawful, I am fearful that all the efforts will be undone as we insist that personnel in stunts and safety must be a member of the Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance, . . . having a minimum of 10 years in the industry. The provisions mean that we have trained, experienced people with a strong body of experience in our industry. General Occupational Health & Safety Legislation is not specific enough to our industry to provide this protection.
She continues:
We have a profession in which we are directly at risk every time we perform and train. We put our lives in each others hands on a daily basis and therefore rely on each other and the safety code.
Another performer writes:
For most performers, the competition is fierce and the only—repeat only—kind of bargaining power one has is a famous TV Week face. We have spent most of our careers working for minimum award rates—
even though the people who wrote this worked as puppeteers on the feature film Babe —
and the likelihood of our being able to command anything above the Victorian minima is extremely low.
I think it would surprise most Australians to know that their artists and performers are amongst the lowest paid workers in the country. For them, award conditions must be protected.

I believe the Victorian industrial relations reforms have been a disaster, a disaster which has provided no benefit for employees, employers or the Victorian economy. This bill emulates much of the Victorian agenda and would take the nation in the same direction. It would allow the re‐emergence of a discredited system by allowing Victorian agreements to override federal awards. It is, in the view of the Democrats, totally unacceptable.

Before closing, I want to talk about important evidence which was put before the Senate committee but not recorded in Hansard. In Sydney, the committee met informally with workers and management of the ICI chemical complex at Botany. I understand that this large workplace has for many years been the battleground of industrial disputes. ICI is now proud of its workplace relations.

Devolution of decision making down to the shop floor; no site closures; no strikes; flexibility in working conditions; higher levels of efficiency and operating profits; higher wages and a very satisfied work force—all this has been the result. It has been the result under the existing industrial relations legislation.

The committee heard the same story at the Cadbury factory in Tasmania. We were told that the very real reforms that had been achieved could not have taken place without the involvement of the union. Workers and management alike have benefited not just in monetary awards but in the dignity and the pride which comes from a cooperative and democratic approach to workplace relations. It is the Democrats' view that this bill in its present form will do nothing to foster such real industrial relations reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —In proposing this workplace relations bill, the government tells us that cooperative workplace relations will create economic prosperity and welfare for the people of Australia. They also say that the legislation will facilitate higher productivity and a flexible labour market, in turn creating higher employment, improved living standards, low inflation and international competitiveness; empower employees and employers by allowing them to make fair and effective agreements, underlaid by a protective safety net; provide freedom of association, letting employees choose whether or not to join a trade union; ensure employee and employer organisations are accountable to their members; create mutually beneficial work practices between employees and employers; and prevent discrimination. These can certainly be regarded as worthwhile objectives on most counts.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Labor Party suggest that a few amendments are appropriate. We suggest the following: a statement regarding better pay, in line with the coalition's policy entitled Better Pay for Better Work; the encouragement of a flexible and fair labour market; the expansion of the safety net reference to include relevant, secure and consistent awards; the explanation that freedom of association should not be interpreted as a reduction of the right of employees to organise and bargain collectively, which includes the right for employees and their unions to organise and negotiate with the full protection of the law; the provision of arbitration where necessary; and, finally, an assurance that international obligations are met. The fundamental objective of increasing productivity, which in turn will create wealth and lift the standard of living for all Australians, is especially important. It was an objective of Labor in government to achieve sustainable productivity increases, and these were delivered.

Workplace relations are the most important factor in Australia's economic future. Australia's future is reliant on our export market. This means we must ensure that we are always ahead of the competition. By having a skilled, efficient, productive work force we will meet this challenge. At the same time, a work force which delivers continuous productivity improvements ensures sustainable economic growth, the creation of wealth which allows for wage rises and strong profits, and the prevention of high inflation.

In terms of its focus on productivity, the government has the right outcome in mind. I think it is safe to say that there is general agreement amongst all senators that Australian's industrial relations system should have a productivity focus. In light of this, the government's proposed legislation must be examined to see if it will, in fact, deliver higher productivity.

The principal determinants of productivity growth are well known. They are strong rates of investment; strong domestic savings; high levels of research and development; the development of worthwhile infrastructure; low business inputs; macro-economic factors—these provide a business climate which reduces investment risk and, therefore, encourage investment, and this is vital, as it means low inflation and sustainable economic growth; and, most importantly, skilled workers—if employees are motivated and skilled, they have the desire and knowledge to be productive and pro‐active in improving their productivity through areas such as process improvement.

BREAK.PARA: Motivated, skilled workers are the fundamental requirement for productivity increases. You can have all the other factors right—the investment dollars, the equipment, a strong macro-economic environment—but, without the commitment of your work force, you will never achieve higher rates of productivity. This is the fundamental flaw in the productivity objective of the government's Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. You do not gain the commitment of your work force to work smarter by reducing their wages and conditions. No worker will make a commitment to improve their skills, increase their productivity and look at ways of improving their employers' profits if they are working under a harsh contract which pays them a low amount for working long hours.
Indeed, the noted American economist Paul Krugman in his book The Age of Diminished Expectations opens by stating:

Productivity isn't everything, but in the long run it is almost everything. A country's ability to improve its standard of living over time depends almost entirely on its ability to raise its output per worker.

In that context, the speech by Mr Bernie Fraser on 5 September in Tokyo is of great interest. He addressed the concept of productivity and made the key point that productivity growth in the 1990s in Australia has increased from two per cent up to 2.75 per cent per annum. This is a much misunderstood figure. If this lift in productivity were to continue for a generation—and there is no reason why it cannot because it is a structural change in the economy—it would result in a rise in real living standard as measured by wages of over 33 per cent. If that lift in productivity were to increase by a further 0.5 per cent per year, the rise in living standards as measured by real wages is almost double.

The former Labor government encouraged the structural changes and legislated for the institutional framework that resulted in that huge lift in productivity. The current government puts that change at risk by pursuing an alternate path of low wage competition.

The bill before the Senate today will result in lower wages and conditions in a range of industries. I know this along with all other Western Australians, because we have experienced a similar industrial relations agenda of unequal bargaining powers and individual agreements. The Commissioner of Workplace Agreements provided a report to the Senate Economic References Committee. It said that over 80 per cent of individual agreements in that state had resulted in wage rises. This at first sounded positive. But by looking at the statistics for overall wages and conditions, a less glowing story was told. Over 50 per cent of employees with workplace agreements had their hours increased; over 67 per cent had their annual leave loading eliminated; over 50 per cent had their penalty rates for working weekends, public holidays and other shift periods eliminated; over 40 per cent had their penalty rates for overtime eliminated; and, most importantly, only 12.9 per cent of those individual workplace agreements in Western Australia had any productivity relationship incentives or comment at all. After trading off these benefits, penalty rates, conditions and other payments, the wage rise of course was illusory. At best, in 80 per cent of the agreements there was an absorption of existing loadings and penalties, and this was disguised as a wage rise.

The Western Australian individual contracts system encouraged the reduction in real wages and competition for low wage jobs in low skilled areas of the economy. This includes cafes, restaurants, independent supermarkets, and similar service industries with low barriers to entry. However, it did not result in higher output per worker, increased employment in those firms or industries, or increased market share for employers in those industries. Indeed, low wage competition in those service industries in Western Australia in the last three years has been of little benefit to either employers or employees.

Employers in the independent supermarkets industry, for example, have seen their market share decrease from 53 per cent in 1993 to 49 per cent in 1996, with a further reduction, according to industry associations, to around 42 per cent over the next five years. Employees lost penalty rates, leave loadings and weekend rates without any guarantee of secure employment or, indeed, additional employment in their firms for other workers.

Oddly enough, that market share was transferred to heavily unionised national and Western Australian based companies which engaged in legitimate enterprise bargaining. These companies focused on improved customer service, high volume turnover, additional staff training, differential products and innovative service techniques. In short, these companies that gained market share in an intensely competitive industry and paid higher wages did so on the basis of improved productivity. As Dr Roy Green, of the Employment Studies Centre at the University of Newcastle told the Senate Economics References Committee:

Low wage competition is not the most effective way of improving productivity. The most effective way of improving productivity is to focus on other aspects of our competitive edge: quality, innovation, delivery and service. These are the areas which—in global markets, anyway—give the greatest benefit to countries which lack the resources we have.

To improve this bill so it really does provide sustained productivity increases we need to remove the parts of the legislation which will reduce wages and conditions and, instead, add ways to deliver win‐win situations for both employers and employees, situations where parties cooperate to achieve productivity increases and where both parties are rewarded.

In my view, there are a number of aspects of the bill which require particular attention by the Senate. They are seven in number. The first is opposition to reducing awards to a mere 18 conditions. The effect of reducing awards is to remove entitlements of workers in a way that is contrary to the Howard government's promises before the election of 2 March 1996. Secondly is the opposition to reducing the powers of the Industrial Relations Commission to 18 conditions. How can an industrial dispute on a matter outside the 18 permitted conditions be resolved if the employer or, for that matter, the employees refuse to negotiate or to reach a sensible agreement and the Industrial Relations Commission is unable to conciliate or arbitrate on this matter?

Thirdly is the opposition to removing the power of the commission to regulate superannuation under the terms of an award. This issue is important because many awards nominate a single industry fund into which superannuation should be paid. Removing the ability of the award to regulate superannuation is introducing unwanted, costly competition without any protection or guarantees. Fourthly is the opposition to removing the ability of awards to regulate part‐time work. It is important to retain existing provisions which regulate the minimum hours a part‐timer can work on any day, the minimum hours a part‐timer can work in a given week, the maximum hours a part‐timer can work in any day as part of ordinary time and the maximum hours which a part‐timer can work in a given week.

Fifthly, the proposed legislation would abolish the ability of the Industrial Relations Commission to scrutinise Australian workplace agreements before they come into force. This change needs to be resisted because it means individual contracts could be applied without any independent scrutiny, thereby endangering existing rates and conditions of workers who go onto such individual contracts. Sixthly is opposition to the right of entry. It is important that unions retain the right to visit any workplace where members or potential members of the union are employed and that they retain the right to be able to look at the wage records of the employer.

Seventhly, a membership agreement should be permitted as part of enterprise bargaining arrangements where an employer and a union have negotiated wages, working conditions, job security and superannuation matters and also dealt with the issue of union membership in an agreement which is endorsed by the workers to whom it applies. By limiting the commission's capacity to prevent and settle industrial disputes, particularly through the introduction of last resort arbitration, the government is discouraging disputes from reaching a quick and effective resolution. This will damage Australia's reputation with our overseas trading partners and will also have a massively detrimental effect on our productivity rates.

The legislation can be improved to deliver the stated productivity outcome. There are specific ways to ensure this happen. Firstly is the institutionalisation of productivity. There must be a productivity culture among all workers, employers and unions. This should become an important focus of our entire industrial relations system. In practice, this means communicating the benefits of productivity increases to almost every member of the work force, something unions have been most effective at doing for the past decade. It means establishing forums at an enterprise level which facilitate employer‐employee discussion and cooperation with a focus on improving productivity. Most importantly, it means forgetting the antiquated idea that industrial relations is a game of us versus them. If we are to succeed in the future as a nation, industrial relations must be about cooperation and working to the mutual benefit of employers and employees.

Secondly is the recognition that only a skilled and motivated work force will deliver the productivity growth that Australia requires to lift our standard of living. This is achieved through providing access to education and training, developing a training culture at an enterprise level, and ensuring employees are encouraged to undertake training.

Thirdly is the establishment of an industrial relations system which acts as an agent of redistribution, without impeding efficiency. To ensure adequate motivation to work smarter and to undertake more training and skills development, workers must share in the rewards of productivity gains. At the same time, however, it is a requirement for all parties to recognise the desirability of adequate profit levels. If companies do not have adequate profits they cannot invest in areas like research and development, and the purchasing of equipment, which would also boost productivity. There can be no argument that wage rises linked to productivity gains are inflationary or unfair to companies. Therefore, these rises should be encouraged. As any worker will tell you, one of the biggest motivators is the contents of the envelope they receive on pay day.

Fourthly is a public policy commitment entrenching the right of individuals and groups to join unions and bargain collectively in the sanctity of a legal system that protects these fundamental rights. This means recognising that unions have a legitimate right to organise and represent their members effectively. It must be recognised that equality is a fundamental requirement for productivity. Employees will not be motivated to work hard if there are huge wage disparities between people performing equal work. At the same time, there should be real freedom for workers to choose whether to be covered by a strong, effective award or collective enterprise agreement or workplace agreement which contains a no disadvantage test.

Real freedom means employees will not be disadvantaged if they decide against signing a workplace agreement. It must be illegal for employers to refuse to employ someone who will not sign an agreement.

Fifthly, there has to be an understanding that an effective industrial relations system imposes obligations as well as responsibilities which are binding on employers, employees and unions. These rights and responsibilities should be written into a bill of rights for employers and employees which ensures mutually agreeable outcomes and the protection of both parties' fundamental rights.

Sixthly, there has to be adequate flexibility to make necessary changes in those areas of the economy which compete internationally, ensuring that they have every opportunity to be successful in the global marketplace. At the same time, there must be a recognition that Australia's export future is not in competing with the lower wage levels of some overseas countries. Rather, one of our key comparative advantages is our highly skilled, innovative and intelligent work force. Our workers may cost more than those of some of our neighbours, but they also produce far more. Lowering wages will only reduce that productivity because workers will lose their commitment and incentive to become skilled.

Seventhly, there has to be facilitation of a quick and effective dispute resolution through the commission. Prolonged disputes harm workers, companies and the nation and must be avoided at all costs. The only way to ensure a fast outcome is to have a commission which has the legal right to resolve disputes. It is only through introducing strategies such as this that you will achieve the stated outcomes of the bill.

In its present form, the bill is a lost opportunity. We are at a crucial point in our nation's future—a point where we must have continuously productive workplaces; otherwise we will not be able to compete effectively in the increasingly global economy.

All this bill offers Australians is a 19th century industrial relations agenda in a 21st century world. The legislation should seek to provide security for the future, not turn the clock back to the insecurities of the past. With the right vision and, in practice, the right amendments, this legislation can still be a groundbreaking act which delivers industrial relations harmony and economic security for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill proposed by the government. Of course, like all members of the opposition, I strongly oppose this bill. I think this bill is a retrograde step in the history of industrial relations in Australia. Our system of industrial relations is by no means perfect but, by comparison with many other places in the civilised world, it has served Australia extremely well over the last 90-odd years since Federation and the historic Higgins case in the early 1900s that established the right for organised labour in this country to be able to bargain and an arbitration system that meant that the balance of power between organised labour and capital was about equal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Higgins case accepted the fact, and the early days of the operation of the arbitration commission established the fact, that an individual employee has not got the same bargaining strength as an employer and the philosophy of industrial relations in this country is to give both sides an even go. The arbitration system was established to take account of the particular role that trade unions, organised labour, have and to ensure that both sides are evenly balanced within the system.

This bill is about tipping the playing field in favour of the employer. That is not surprising coming from an ideologically right wing driven new government that has been going on about some of these issues for nearly a decade. I would presume that this is very similar but not quite the same as what Mr Hewson was promising in Fightback. But if it is not the complete daughter of Fightback it is very close to it—to reduce the power of ordinary employees to get a reasonable go in this country.

Around the world the history of Australia's industrial relations and arbitration system is well known. Of course, it is interesting to note that way back in 1929 another conservative liberal Prime Minister—it was called the National Party in those days—Mr Bruce decided to try to destroy the arbitration system in this country. He went to an election and got soundly defeated and had the ignominy of being the only sitting Prime Minister in Australia's history to lose his seat. That was the last time a coalition government or a conservative government tried to play around with the arbitration system in a fundamental way. The conservative Prime Minister of the day lost his seat and his party suffered a grievous defeat at that time.

Here again, we have a conservative coalition attempting to turn the clock back on industrial relations to an age that no longer exists, to a golden age where employers were able to do what they liked and employees basically had no rights. This is the first step to winding back. That is why we oppose this bill in philosophical terms.

Today I want to talk about the impact on small business. As minister for small business in the previous government, I was fully aware of the concern in the small business community about the impact of the unfair dismissal amendments that went through in 1993-94. I was involved in discussions with the small business community, the small business forum, about their concerns about the process of that legislation—how it was clumsy, how it was tortuous and how, in the end, commonsense in outcomes was not able to be achieved because of the processes that were outlined when the case went to the industrial court.

As a result of those discussions, I raised these matters with the then Prime Minister and the industrial relations minister and major changes were made in legislation on unfair dismissals. They went through the parliament in the last half of last year. They came into effect on 15 January this year. As of yet, we have not got complete data available on the number of unfair dismissal cases being taken since those amendments came into effect on 15 January. But all the indications, I am told, are that there has been a significant drop in the number of unfair dismissal cases taken since 15 January. This, of course, reflects the effect of those changes.

Those changes were to make the operation of the legislation simpler, less legalistic and, above all else, to make sure that the court could take into account the broad circumstances of the particular case, not just a narrow legal process approach. I think that certainly was the intent. I think that is why some of the capricious cases were taken.

As small business minister, I noticed that many of the applications that occurred after the legislation first went through at the end of 1993, early 1994, that established unfair dismissals were not actually coming all the time from the blue collar area; they were coming from middle management. Middle management discovered for the first time that they could take a case against their employer about being dismissed. They were the ones who quickly took the opportunity.

Because initially there was no cap on the amount you could claim, some of the claims for loss for unfair dismissal from some of these middle managers were, in my view, quite outrageous, running into hundreds of thousands of dollars and in some cases over $1 million. That was not the intent of the legislation. It is interesting to note that a number of these people from middle management, who are probably not noted to be Labor supporters, were willing to take advantage of the legislation.

BREAK.PARA: So we amended the legislation. I think overwhelmingly it has achieved the effect that everybody in Australia would have liked to have seen. Now the government is moving to amend it further. Under the unfair dismissal area, the government is transferring to the industrial commission the unfair dismissal cases that are now being dealt with in the industrial court. We have already warned the government that we put it in the industrial court because there was some doubt about the constitutionality of putting cases of unfair dismissal in the industrial commission.

We still believe that there may be constitutional issues, but we are not opposed to putting those cases to the industrial commission. If that goes through and they are not challenged constitutionally, that, obviously, would be a further step in ensuring that the cases are dealt with in a commonsense, broad approach way rather than in a narrow legalistic way involving the cost of lawyers, et cetera. That is a good move, but we did not do it because we were advised of the constitutionality issues of having such cases dealt with by the industrial commission rather than by the industrial court.

The second area the government has proposed is limiting jurisdiction in the way the unfair dismissal laws could operate. We do not support that. We think the government has got itself into a bit of a tangle about this because it does not want to use the external power provisions in respect of jurisdiction. This, of course, is an ideologically driven view of some members of the opposition that they should under no circumstances at any stage on any issue use external powers because using external powers means that the supremacy of this parliament over state rights is clear.

There are many in the coalition who believe that state rights should overwhelm the power of the federal parliament. We make no bones about it. We believe the national parliament should have these powers. We are all Australians first before we are South Australians, Western Australians or Victorians. That is the way it should be. Many people, even people from the employer side from time to time, have said all industrial relations matters should be referred to the federal jurisdiction. I certainly have had that view for a long time.

I think we will end up with a better industrial relations system if we use the powers and legislation of this parliament. It would be a much better industrial relations system than having six different states and two territories running industrial relations. The sooner the coalition parties accept that the only way this country is going to succeed economically is to ensure that we run Australia as Australia and not as six separate states based on a colonial mentality the better. That is the way Australia is going to be able to have the best advantage economically in an internationally competitive economy, not running six states based on a colonial mentality.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said the ACTU is running it.
—Senator Campbell—whose views are well known—made a remarkable maiden speech in this place.

—I sat and listened with some astonishment that a senator in the federal parliament basically made a speech saying that all power should reside with the state governments. He accused the federal parliament of having too much power. He comes here and then says, `Don't give me the power to do anything.' That was the philosophical thrust of Senator Campbell's remarks in his maiden speech. At that stage, he came in here as one of Senator Crichton-Browne's acolytes—

—Withdraw the statement please.
—As it is unparliamentary, I withdraw it.

—I knew I would touch a sensitive point in raising his maiden speech. I have to say to Senator Campbell: the longer you have been here, your views have moderated on this issue because you have realised—

BREAK.PARA: The third part of the unfair dismissal legislation which we oppose is the proposal by the government to limit the amounts of compensation—and it is capped—and by the description according to the viability of the firm. We believe that, though that might have some immediate populist reasoning, it will create enormous legal difficulties in determining the viability of a firm. It means that, if the firm is doing better, someone can get a higher amount of compensation for an unfair dismissal—irrespective of the merits or the demerits of their dismissal.

So we believe the measures that are being proposed with great fanfare by the new government to meet their promises, particularly to the small business community, really have been overtrumpeted. Basically the amendments that we put through—which came into effect on 15 January with the support of the then small business community, the small business forum—have addressed, overwhelmingly, the concerns of that community. That is why the numbers of complaints have now substantially dropped off.

I also want to talk about what I think is wrong with this bill from a small business perspective. Despite all of the publicity and all of the argument about whether the unfair dismissal rules were affecting employment in the small business community, if one goes back and looks at the amount of employment that increased in Australia from 1993-94 through to the end of last year, the numbers of employed people in Australia went up by several hundred thousand. All the figures show that the largest proportion of that area came from people in the small business community, which was employing people.

I accept that someone might say, `Well, they would have employed even more if they had not had unfair dismissal rules.' That may be the case. But to say, as the coalition put it, that these unfair dismissal laws meant that there was no employment increase going on is just wrong and is not supported by the facts. There were several hundred thousand new jobs created in Australia during that period 1993-96, and a majority of those were in the small business sector.

I want to make another point about the impact of employment in small business. When you go and visit many of the small businesses in the manufacturing industry and the services industry you soon find that unfair dismissal was not the major issue that they saw as contributing to difficulties for their business. There were a range of issues, and some of them are well known.

One of the things that struck me when I visited many of these small businesses—and I visited several hundred during the three years I was minister—is that the businesses that were doing the best clearly had excellent industrial relations that they had sorted out themselves. Even within the award structure, even within the existing rules and laws, they had worked out very sensibly the best way their business could operate. There was cooperation and complete understanding between the employer—who, in most cases, was both the owner and the manager of the business—and his or her employees.

You saw excellent achievement in productivity, in innovation and in R&D. You knew that these businesses were getting into the export business. They were able to sort out very happily and quite properly within the existing structure ways to get rid of senseless demarcation disputes between jobs, to improve skilling and to improve training—all of that was occurring.

When I visited those several hundred firms that were doing well, you never got many complaints—if any at all—on the operation of the industrial relations system. They said, `So long as we can negotiate a flexible approach that is fair to our employees about the way the business is conducted to improve the profitability and to improve the quality of our product, we are more than happy with it.' In fact, a number of small businesses said to me, `We would prefer to continue to operate within the award structure rather than have to negotiate an individual arrangement with every employee. So long as the award gives us the flexibility'—and it does—`we are more than happy with it, because we know what it provides and the employees know what it provides. Where there are areas of change needed, we can make those arrangements.'

The industrial relations aspects of this bill are not taking account of the fact that there has been a culture change in Australia over the last 10 to 15 years, from both employers and employees in the mainstream, about the way business and industry should be conducted. The issue is not about one side condemning the other. I did go to some businesses which had the old‐style approach of `them' and `us'. They were competing against each other, and you saw a business that was dying. When you saw one where there was good cooperation and understanding and respect on both sides, you saw a business that was growing.

This bill is aiming to take people back to reduce their wages, to make them cannon fodder and to basically say, `When you come to work, you leave your brains at the front door.' Rather, they should be saying—and most modern businesses now have this approach—that the best asset of their business is the quality and intellect of their workers. They should be giving them the opportunity in the workplace to contribute not just to producing an item but to ways of improving the value added of that particular business.

Those businesses are the ones that are the future of Australia. I think it is disappointing that the government still has an attitude based on the 1960s or 1970s at the latest—more likely the 1920s of former Prime Minister Bruce—to try to destroy the rights of workers, either individually or collectively, where they want to organise trade unions to represent them in sensible negotiations.

This bill, if it is passed in any form that comes out of the discussions in this place, will not be the panacea for employment growth in this country. It will not be the panacea for economic growth. It will be a retrograde step that does no justice to the rights of not only workers but sensible employers in this country.

INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT (FAMILY TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996

Madam President, this bill, together with the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996, will give effect to the centrepiece of the government's election commitment to Australian families, the family tax initiative.

Almost two million families with dependent children—the majority of Australian families with dependent children—will receive a major boost from this initiative. It will direct around $1 billion a year extra to families, providing much needed extra help in bringing up children.
The family tax initiative will commence on 1 January 1997.

The family tax initiative is a clear example of the government's commitment to giving families greater choice in how they spend their hard earned cash and in how they juggle work and family responsibilities. Each family is the best judge of what it needs, and the government's program of reforms reflect that approach.

The family tax initiative provides two forms of assistance. Part A has the effect of increasing the tax free threshold by $1,000 for one parent in a family for each dependent child up to the age of 16 years and each dependent secondary student up to 18 years. This assistance will be available to families that have a combined taxable income of less than $70,000, with an increase of $3,000 for each child after the first. By increasing the threshold, tax at the rate of 20 cents in the dollar is saved, with the effect that eligible families receive the equivalent of an increase of $200 per annum in their disposable income for each dependent child.

Additional assistance, Part B of the initiative, will be directed towards single income families, including lone parents, with young children. There will be an increase in the tax free threshold of $2,500 for one parent in those families who have at least one child aged under five years and provided that the breadwinner's income is less than $65,000 per annum (with an increase of $3,000 for each child after the first) and the spouse's income is less than the income cut‐off for basic parenting allowance (currently $174.43 per fortnight). The alignment of the spouse's income test with the cut‐off for basic parenting allowance provides a realistic measure of the workforce activity of the principal carer and ensures greater consistency in the treatment of predominantly single income families. This assistance will give families the equivalent of an increase in their disposable income of $500 per annum (around $19.20 per fortnight).

There are two methods of delivery for the family tax initiative. First, the majority of eligible families with children will be assisted through the income tax system. This bill gives effect to the tax free threshold adjustments to deliver both Part A and Part B assistance to families.

Low income families will be able to receive the family tax initiative as a fortnightly direct payment through the Department of Social Security. Some 900,000 families will receive an immediate boost to their disposable income through this measure. The extra fortnightly amount will be known as the family tax payment and will ensure that low income families, who might not have a high enough tax liability to benefit fully from the changes to the tax system, will get the help they need when they need it most. Amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 to provide for family tax payments are contained in the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 which is being introduced as part of this package.

Madam President, the government recognises that providing an economic and social environment in which families can achieve their full potential is crucial to maintaining a strong, cohesive and compassionate society. Providing financial assistance to those families with the greatest need is an investment in that economic and social environment.

The pressures that families face in juggling their work and child raising responsibilities are arguably greater today than ever before. One of the keys to relieving these pressures is to increase the real opportunities available to families and to give them more genuine choices about how they live. The government has a commitment to pursue policies that enable families to choose how they balance their work and child raising responsibilities. The government is committed to ensuring that families with young children are given greater freedom to choose whether one parent cares full‐time for their children at home or whether both are in the paid workforce.
The family tax initiative acknowledges the central role that families have in supporting the foundation of Australian society
I commend the bill to the Senate.
FAMILY (TAX INITIATIVE) BILL 1996

This bill, together with the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 which has just been introduced, will give legislative effect to the centrepiece of the Government's election commitment to Australian families, the family tax initiative.

The bill provides that low income families will be able to receive the family tax initiative as a fortnightly direct payment through the Department of Social Security, rather than through the tax system.

Some 900,000 families will receive an immediate boost to their disposable income through this measure. The extra fortnightly amount will be known as the family tax payment and will ensure that low income families, who might not have a high enough tax liability to benefit fully from the changes to the taxation system, will get the help they need when they need it most.

The bill also makes minor amendments to the tax law that are consequential to the introduction of the family tax initiative, over and above those made in the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996.
I commend the bill to the Senate,.
